Sternhold to be certain that these letters have passed through no other hands than yours. Hawksley seals the packet and hands it to Mildmay And there is the forged bill! (giving bill to Hawksey

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (examines the bill, then burns it by taper, and throws it to the ground, stamping on it. Aside.) Gone! He knows nothing of the other.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (taking his hat from table L.) And now, Captain Burgess—I mean Hawksley—I have the honour to wish you a very good morning.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (crossing to him.) Stop ! A word before you go. Since we had first the pleasure of meeting, I've been a soldier, and have served in countries where blood wipes out disgrace. What are your weapons ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I thought it might come to that; but you needn't trouble yourself to call me out, because I shan't come.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: And do you flatter yourself I can't force you ? I know duelling is out of fashion in this infernal coldblooded country; but, even here, there are insults a man can't put up with, and hold his head up before the world — take care I don't put such an insult upon you. (drawing near, and lifting up his hanD.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Don't try {that} on again: I may be less patient the second time. I might send you into the street without the trouble of going down stairs; there's two stories' fall, not to speak of the area spikes : you might hurt yourself.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: Very well. We are by ourselves — there would be no use in insulting you here : but take care ; the first time we meet in company, I will lash you across the face with my horsewhip. We shall see then if you will refuse me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: We shall. If you were only a duellist, I doubt if I should think myself bound to risk my life against yours. But I presume even the laws which you recognise absolve me from the obligation of going out with a swindler and a forger.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (grinding his teeth.) Do you wish to provoke me to murder you ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p:
Oh, I'm not the least afraid of that. For a man who can snuff a candle at twenty paces, to call out another who never fired a pistol in his life, is no great piece of heroism; but to commit a murder requires some pluck. You've defied transportation, but I
don't think you're the man to risk the gallows. Good morning. (he turns to go L,. D. 2 E.)

div.stage: Tableau and end of Act the SeconD.

div.head: Act III.
div.stage: Scene . — Scene and Furniture same as Act I. Keys in doors, R. and l. 1 e. Mrs. Sternhold seated in easy chair by fire r. h. ; Mrs. Mildmay sitting on sofa, writing at table l. ; Potter standing l. c, looking over her.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L. C.) If you don't make haste, Emmy, we shan't be able to get the letters delivered, putting off our dinner to-day, in consequence of the sudden indisposition of Mrs. Sternhold.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: This is the last, papa, It's just five—Jessop will have time enough to deliver them all before six.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (crossing to Mrs. SternholD.) How do you feel now, my dear Jane ? (Mrs. Sternhold turns from him impatiently.) I'm really very sorry that I endorsed those shares to Mildmay, as it annoys you, but he said he had settled it with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Dear, dear brother—will you spare me any further allusion to the subject. My head aches dreadfully.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Poor dear! Pull the curtains to, Emmy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: No, no—leave them, pray ! And leave me, do!

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p:
I can't think what Mildmay can have meant, by telling me he'd settled it all with you. Eh! here he comes, to give us an explanation.
Enter Mildmay, L. D. 1 E. Oh! here you are! Well, you're a cool hand.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Didn't you tell me, before going into town this morning, when you asked me to endorse those shares to you, that you had settled it all with Mrs. Sternhold ? And now, it seems, she knew nothing about it. My dear Jane, I wish him to explain himself before you. Mildmay, I insist upon a categorical answer. Did you, or did you not, tell me it was all settled between you and Mrs. Sternhold?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (L. C.) I told you so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (R.) Mr. Mildmay, do you mean to say I expressed any wish of the kind ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: You never said a word to me on the subject.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R. aside.) What does he mean by contradicting himself in this extraordinary way? He must have been lunching with Hawksley. He's had too much wine!

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (R. C.) Mr. Mildmay, I insist on your explaining the meaning of your conduct!

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: With pleasure! I couldn't dispose of the shares till they came into my hands, and it occurred to me that the best way of getting them into my hands from Mr. Potter's, was to use your name.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R.) But do you mean to say you have disposed of the shares I endorsed to you ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I certainly have taken that liberty.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (aside.) Oh! he must have been lunching! There's a coolness about him that's perfectly unnatural!

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: I hate mystification! Will you oblige me, Mr. Mildmay, by stating, simply and distinctly, what you really have done with those shares!

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p:
Certainly. I was much struck, last night, with the justice of Mr. Potter's observations on the danger
of such speculations as Captain Hawksley's—so, instead of taking any new shares, I've let the captain have the old one's back again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: And do you mean to say he has taken them ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Certainly—at par. Here's the money.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (crosses to C.) Do you mean to say he made no difficulty about it ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes—he did a little—but we got over that. There is the thousand pounds. (gives notes to Potter.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: My dear John, I've done you injustice. Would you believe it ? I thought you were tipsy—that Hawksley had been making you drink, in order to humbug you into buying—and now, it seems, you've humbugged {him} into buying. Who'd have thought you had had it in you ? Would you have thought he had it in him, Jane ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (crossing to Mrs. Mildmay.) Have you finished those letters, Emily ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: I've only to direct them, aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: I'll direct them if you'll tell Jessop to get ready to take them at once.
sp.stage: (Mrs Mildmay rises and Exits L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: And I'll just lock up these notes in my escritoire ! [ Exit Potter, L. D. 1 E.

div.stage: (Mrs. Sternhold sits on sofa, and addresses a letter or two.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (C.) Why, you're sending out a circular?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: It is to put off the people we had invited to dine to-day. I'm too ill to receive them. Did I understand you to say you had seen Captain Hawksley this morning ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes. I left him not long ago.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: And when you offered him the shares, he took them without making any objections ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I over-ruled his objections.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Can you inform me by what means ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Oh! what matter about the means, when the end's attained?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: S. Did nothing pass between you, on any other subject than these shares ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Oh—yes — we did touch upon other matters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (uneasily.) But nothing of any particular interest—nothing in which any of us were concerned ?

div.stage: (Mildmay takes out the packet of letters, and puts it on the table before her. Mrs Sternhold snatches up the packet, and recognizes Hawksley's seal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: His seal! (she tears open the packet and recognises her letters. Rises, and comes to L. C.) You have saved my good name ! I owe you more than I can ever repay—more than life itself!

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (quietly.) Hadn't you better lock up those letters, before anybody sees them ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Stay! (breaks the seal, and is about to count them.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: You may save yourself the trouble—they're all there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: All?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Thirteen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Then you have counted them?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes—but I've no notion what they're about. He sealed them up, as you see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: John Mildmay, you have acted like a gentleman. Forgive me for my conduct to you—I cannot forgive myself. To think that I should have doubted you, at the very moment you were about to do me a service which a life of gratitude cannot pay for.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I shall be satisfied with a good deal less than that. I see you're better already. Oblige me by not putting off your dinner to-day.

div.stage: Mrs. Sternhold goes to table, L., and begins to tear up the letters written by Mrs. Mildmay, and throws scraps into a waste paper basket.
Re-enter Potter, L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Jessop's ready to start. Why, if she isn't tearing up the letters ! My dear Jane, what are you about ? I'm sure Emmy had written them very neatly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (C.) I've changed my mind, brother. The dinner is not to be put off.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L.) Well, but my dear Jane—consider your head-ache—and allow me to observe—

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p:
My dear brother, allow {me} to observe that I'm
the best judge of my own state of health—and go and tell Jessop he will not be wanted to carry the letters.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (going L.) Very well, my dear ! (aside.) Now that's sheer strength of mind! What a woman she is ! 'Gad, she rises from her prostration like a—what's its name—the bird over the fire offices—a phœnix.
sp.stage: [ Exit potter l . D. 1 e.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (crosses to R. C, and sits.) And now that we are alone, tell me what has passed between you and this man ? By what magic have you tamed his insolent and pitiless nature ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (L. C.) Why dwell on details which could only give you pain ? From to-day, let all that has passed, relative to this affair, be forgotten between us. As you said this morning, I have but paid a debt of duty to our relationship. You have got rid of a disreputable acquaintance; take my advice, and don't renew it. (sits.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Renew it! Never! He was, included in our dinner party to-day—but after what must have passed between you, I suppose there's no danger of our seeing him.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I've no doubt he'll come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: He dare not.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Oh yes, he dare! Assurance is his strong point. But don't be afraid—I shall be here. Receive him as usual, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (with surprise.) John Mildmay! there's something in your manner to-day I have never seen before— a coolness, a self-possession, an energy I never should have expected from—from—

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: From such a spoon—that's what you mean, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: No—that's not the word.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: It's about the idea, though. But you're wrong. I'm the same man to-day as I was yesterday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: John Mildmay, you're a perfect puzzle.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Have you any curiosity about the key ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Curiosity! I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p:
I'm a man—and not an automaton, as you've always considered me—that's all! Listen to me. We {must} have an explanation—and this is the time for it.
I'm neither a hero nor a conjuror, but I'm a straightforward man, and I'm not deficient in common sense. When I married your niece, I looked forward to a quiet life, with a woman I loved in my own undemonstrative way, and who, I thought, would have loved me—and so she would have done, but for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: But for me!

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes ! She has been brought up to think you infallible. Had you treated me with respect and consideration, she would have done so too. You thought proper to ridicule and despise me, and she followed your lead. I saw this, even during our honeymoon. For ten months I've tried what patience, indulgence, and submission would do—that plan has been a failure. From this hour, I change my tactics. You are my wife's nearest female relative, and you shall never find me wanting in duty or respect, but, from this day forth, remember, there's only one master in this house, and his name is John Mildmay. (rises.) Now, go and dress for dinner. (she attempts to speak.) Go and dress for dinner. (Politely handing Mrs. Sternhold towards R. D. 1 E. [ Exit Mrs. Sternhold, R. D. And now for Emily. Poor girl! Last night's lesson was a hard one, but she brought it on herself. It will do no harm. Enter Mrs. Mildmay, L. D, 1 E. Sit down Emily. (Mrs. Mildmay sits L. C.) How well you look.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: A compliment from you! I thought you had forgotten how to pay one.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Did you, Emily ? You remember what day this is ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Yes. (with a sigh.) The anniversary of our marriage.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Does it come round as such a day should, Emily ? Do you remember the vows we both took this day twelvemonth?—"To love, to honour, and obey."

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (surpriseD.) What do you mean, John ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: They did well, the compilers of that solemn service, to put {love} first—for it carries with it both the others. Have you kept that vow, Emily ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (agitateD.) I do not understand you!

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Emily, I returned to this house, last night, half-an-hour before you saw me. I overheard all that passed between your aunt and Captain Hawksley, I knew the motive of his intrusion into this house at that hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (starting up.) Spare me! Forgive me! I was foolish! I listened to him—but I never thought he could have dared— Indeed, John, I never did. And I wished to tell you all before you went—to implore you to stay and watch over me—to guard me from the consequences of—my folly ! (sinking her head on his shoulder.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (gravely.) Compose yourself, Emily! I have too much fairness to confound folly with guilt. Why, my poor child, I knew that fellow's game. I saw how his romantic airs, his honeyed words, and showy graces had fascinated you—how, in comparison with him, you thought me cold, awkward, uninteresting, unimpassioned. You are not the first of your sex, Emmy, who has prefered the shadow to the substance. Thank heaven you have not been awakened from your dream by the suffering that follows upon sin! Don't speak, my love, but listen. Your father's doting fondness, and your aunt's mischievous example have made you what you are. Trust to me, henceforth, to make you what a wife should be. I should prefer to win you by a lover's tenderness, but, if I cannot do that, I know how to make a husband's rights respected.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, dearest; thank you—tell me of my faults—I will try to correct them. I will honour and obey you, as a wife should.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I've been to blame, too. I have been rough, and cold, and careless—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: No—no; you are the kindest and most generous of men. But my father—my aunt—they have been as much mistaken in you as I was. Speak to her, as you have spoken to me.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p:
(with a smile.) I don't love her as I love you. But, make yourself easy—I {have} spoken to her, and in a way I don't think she will soon forget. And now,
go, darling, and dry your eyes—and come down to our guests, smiling as a wife, should smile when she meets her husband's loving looks, (kisses her.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Oh, bless you—bless you for such words! How have I misjudged you !

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (suppressing his emotion.) Go—go—dear. Remember, I've my eyes to dry, too.
sp.stage: [ Exit Mrs. Mildmay, L. D. 3 E. Thank heaven, that's over ! I've played a desperate game, but I've won it, and the stake was worthy of the risk.
[ Exit, door L,. U. E.

div.stage: Enter Potter, dressed for dinner, L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Six o'clock, and Mildmay not dressed yet. Egad ! (rubbing his hands.) He'll be unpunctual for once. Well, I'm glad Jane's better, for we shall be a pleasant party, I flatter myself. There's Dunbilk, an uncommonly pleasant fellow, and— (bell hearD.) Oh! I dare say that's Joe Langford. Joe's always sharp—military time, as he calls it—and a military appetite.

div.stage: Enter Jessop, announcing, L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Jessop.
sp.p: Mr. Langford!
sp.stage: Enter Langford, L. D. 1 E., crosses to R. [ Exit Jessop.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R. C.) Ah, Langford, my dear fellow, delighted to see you. Mrs. Sternhold will be down directly. Well, (rubbing his hands.) any news to-day ?

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: (R. by fire-place.) Nothing particular. Uncommonly seasonable weather.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Uncommonly seasonable weather — uncommonly seasonable—uncommonly— (bell hearD.) I shouldn't wonder if that's Markham.

div.stage: Enter Jessop, announcing, L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Jessop.
sp.p: Mr. Markham.
sp.stage: Enter Markham, L. D. 1 E., crosses to fire-place, R.
[ Exit Jessop, L.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Ah! it is Markham! How are you all at home ?—that's right! You know Langford, I think. (Langford and Markham bow.) Well, anything new?

sp.speaker: Markham.
sp.p: No — nothing stirring but stagnation! Infernally disagreeable weather—

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Infernally disagreeable—infernally—very disagreeable weather! (aside.) I wish Jane would come! She has such a flow of conversation. Enter Mrs. Sternhold, R. D. 1 E., and Mrs. Mildmay,L. D. 3 e. Ah! here she is! Mr. Langford—my dear—Mr. Markham.

div.stage: (The gentlemen bow to the ladies, and enter into conversation, near fire-place, R.H.
Enter Jessop announcing.

sp.speaker: Jessop.
sp.p: Mr. Dunbilk.
sp.stage: Enter Dunbilk, L,. D. 1 E. Exit Jessop, L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: (L. C.) Mrs. Sternhold! Mrs. Mildmay! How are you, Potter ? I was afraid I'd be afther me time— waiting for Hawksley. He promised to drive me here in his cab, and I waited till I was too late, and powdhered down in a Hansom, ten mile an hour. You expect Hawksley, don't you ?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (C.) Eh? Oh, yes, we rely on the captain. My women-folk, here, would never forgive me if we gave a dinner without asking the captain. I assure you, they pull caps for him—aunt and niece. Don't you, Emmy ? I think I'm right in saying the captain's a bit of a favourite, eh, Jane ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (evading the question.) We certainly did expect Captain Hawksley, but he's not always to be relied on.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Ye may say that, ma'am—run afther as he is by the aristocracy, (aside.) not to spake of the sheriff's officers.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (R. C.) I beg your pardon—I fear I have kept you waiting.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L. C.) Oh, Captain Hawksley hasn't come yet.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Sure I wouldn't wait for him, if I was you. He'd be sorry, if he does come, to think he spoiled the fish.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: No—we'll give him a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (aside to Mrs. Sternhold, down R. H.) Surely he will not dare to show himself here, after last night!

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (aside to Mas. Mildmay, down R. H.) You have seen what he dares do, already!

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I hope he won't disappoint us. I never felt so anxious to see him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (aside.) I am sick with apprehension.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (aside.) Oh, what will happen, if he and John meet!

div.stage: Enter Jessop, L. D. 1 E. ,with a card on salver.

sp.speaker: Jessop.
sp.p: (crosses to mildmay.) A gentleman wishes to see you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (coming down R. C.) A friend of mine come to town unexpectedly. May I ask him to join us ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (R.) In your own house! My dear John,, you surely need not ask that question.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L. C.) Jane!

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (R.) Show him in, directly.
sp.stage: [ Exit Jessop L.D.1e
sp.p: I'm sure we must all be glad to see any friend of yours my love. .

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Emily ! (aside.) What's come to the women?

div.stage: (goes up . Enter Jessop, showing in Gimlet , L. D. 1 E Exit Jessop.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (crossing to L. C.) This is my friend,—

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: Maxwell—

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Mr. Maxwell, from the North.

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: (L.) Ladies, delighted to make your acquaintance—gents all.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (aside to him) Silence! wait till I tell you.

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: All right! (Mildmay and Gimlet go up C.
sp.stage: Enter Jessop L. D. 1 E. announcing.

sp.speaker: Jessop.
sp.p: Captain Hawksley! Exit, Jessop.

p.stage: Enter Captain Hawksley, (fashionably dresseD.) L . D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (crossing to C .) Ah ! Mrs. Sternhold, I hope you are better. No trace of yesterday's headache ? Mrs. Mildmay, I hope you caught no cold sitting up last night over your novel. Ah, you really should be more, careful of yourself. My dear Potter, thank you particularly for letting me have those shares this morning. How do, Dunbilk ? How do, Markham? Good day, Mr. Langford. (turning to Mildmay who is up C .) Mr. John Mildmay ! (a dead silence.) A word with you, sir. (Mrs. Sternhold crosses to L. C. Mildmay comes down R.C. ) I told you what you must expect if ever we met in company. As you seem to have forgotten it, I must remind you.
sp.stage: (He raises his arm to strike Mildmay with horsewhip, which he draws from his pocket. Mrs. Sternhold stays his arm.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Stop! My dear Mrs. Sternhold, don't be alarmed—this is no scene for ladies. Oblige me by walking into the next room for a few minutes.

div.stage: (The Gentlemen all gather round Hawksley C.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: For Mercy's sake

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: John ! Husband !

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I must insist on your going.

div.stage: (Mildmay puts them off R. DS. 1 E. and locks door, then crosses to and locks L. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L.C.) Captain Hawksley, what is the meaning of this behaviour ?

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (c .) It means that your son-in-law, after grossly insulting me this morning, refused me the satisfaction of a gentleman. I told him I would force it from him by the public outrage I have just inflicted. Dunbilk, you'll act as my friend!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Delighted me boy !

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: If this goes on I'll send for the police !

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Lang.
sp.p: Really, Captain Hawksley—

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (authoritatively L.) Not a word more—this is my affair! Mr. Potter, you have pistols in the house! (crosses to R.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L.) Yes, but I won't allow anybody to use them—they're out of condition — they're dangerous— they'll burst.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (R.) No matter, I have taken the liberty to bring them down. Here they are. (opens box.) I'm no fire-eater, but I won't baulk Captain Hawksley of the satisfaction he desires; Markham, you will act for me. Mr. Dunbilk, you represent my antagonist, I think ?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Here ! police ! Jessop ! (all murmur.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Be quiet, I insist—all of you. My mind is made up. Nothing can change it.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (aside.) He has more pluck than I gave him credit for. I will kill him though.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I hold you all to witness what passed. I am the insulted. I have the choice of time, place and weapons. I make that choice. Here—now— these pistols.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (C.) I'm ready—load away, gentlemen.

div.stage: (Dunbilk begins to load pistol R.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (crossing to R. C.) You have often boasted you can hit the pip of an ace at twenty paces. I never fired a pistol at anything more formidable than a sparrow. —I am willing to risk my life against yours on equal terms; but if we stand up opposite to each other at twelve paces, each with a loaded pistol—skill against no skill— what becomes of the equality of risk ? (crosses back to R. H.) Your friend has loaded one of these pistols—let us leave the, other unloaded—put both under the cloth—each draw one, and fire together across the table: now, close your eyes, and choose—you hesitate !

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: Such, a way of fighting was never known but in a novel. I decline this unheard-of mode of proceeding.

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: I expected as much. I only wished to show these gentlemen that under cover of the forms of a duel, you contemplated assassination. (goes to door R. H., and unlocks it.) The storm is passed, ladies.
sp.stage: Re-enter Mrs. Sternhold and Mrs. Mildmay, R. D. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (L. C. to Mildmay.) This bravado shall not serve your turn, sir; we have not done with each other yet,

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (R .C.) You are right, — we have not. Captain Hawksley has insulted me—I have challenged him—he has refused: had he challenged me, {I} might have refused ; for no man, even by the code of society, is bound to go out with a felon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A felon !

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: A felon in this house ! Where ? Police ! Police !

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: (coming down L. C.) Here you are, guv'nor ! (handcuffs Hawksley.) Sorry for it Mr. Boscawen ; but I've been wanting you this long time.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (L.) Boscawen ! This is Captain Hawksley !
sp.stage: [ goes up L.

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: Alias Burgess'—alias Boscawen. It's on a charge of forgery, committed four years ago—evidence only completed last week. It's a lifer, as sure as my name's Gimlet.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: (aside to Gimlet.) You're done, my boy! The bill's destroyed !

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: A bill; but not {the} bill. This is the other.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: Done !—done by that wo1f in sheep's clothing ! (Stands for a moment overpowered, then rouses himself. Some ridiculous blunder—It will be set right this evening.

sp.speaker: Gimlet.
sp.p: That's right, keep your pecker up.

div.stage: (Mildmay gives key of door L. H. to Gimlet - he opens it.

sp.speaker: Hawks.
sp.p: Mrs. Sternhold, I am sorry I shall not have the pleasure of dining with you: Mrs. Mildmay, no chance of another tete-a-tete, I fear : Potter, my boy, you were just in time with those shares; give my compliments to the Board, Dunbilk: Mildmay—(grinding his teeth) if ever I come back, I shall make a point of repaying all I owe you; and, till then, I shall let the debt accumulate at compound interest.
sp.stage: [ Exeunt Captain Hawksley and Gimlet, L. D. 1 R .

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R. C.) I'm bewildered! What does this mean ?

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: (L. C.) It means, my dear Mr. Potter, that straightforward honesty is generally a match for plausible roguery in the long run.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R. C.) Jane, can you explain this ? You're the only person that ever can explain things in this house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: (R.) You are wrong, brother—wrong, as we have all been. Henceforth, for explanation, for advice, for guidance, look there. (pointing to Mildmay.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Why that's poor John Mildmay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. S.
sp.p: Your daughter's husband. (putting Mrs. Mildmay across to Mildmay.) The master of this house!

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: (R. C. ) John Mildmay the master of this house ? Emily, my dear, has your aunt been—I mean has your aunt lost her wits ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: (C.) No, she has found them, papa, as I have done, thanks to dear John. Ask his pardon, papa, as we have, for the cruel injustice we have done him.
sp.stage: (gets up a little.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Oh, certainly, if you desire it. John Mildmay, I ask your pardon—Jane and Emily say I ought; though what I've done, or what there is to ask pardon for—

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll learn in time. But we're forgetting dinner—Langford, will you take my wife? (he does so . Markham, you'll take Mrs. Sternhold.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: My dear boy, you astonish me ! But, however, there's an old proverb that says,— " All is not gold that glitters."

sp.speaker: Mildmay.
sp.p: Yes; and there is another old proverb, and one much more to the purpose, that says,— "Still Waters Run Deep."

div.stage: Disposition of Characters at EnD.
